text: Overall color multiplier. It should be used with caution, as a non-white value breaks physicality. The prefered way to define the color of a conductor is through the Fresnel attributes right below.

Switches the Fresnel parameterization between Artistic and Scientific mode. The Artistic mode offers two colors, one defining the reflectivity in the normal direction, and the other when going towards grazing angles. The Scientific mode proposes an index of refraction and its imaginary counterpart, also called extinction coefficient. Both parameterizations can achieve identical results, as one can be mapped to the other.
Color reflected by the surface in the normal direction.

Indicates how the reflected color curve evolves between its value in the normal direction (or 0 degree), and 1 when reaching 90 degrees. Note that this color is unlikely to be reached, and just bends the curve towards it when reaching grazing angles. A null value does not deviate the curve at all.
Index of refraction (often denoted by 'eta'), defining the color reflected by the surface in the normal direction.

Extinction coefficient (often denoted by 'kappa'), influencing how the reflected color curve evolves between its value in the normal direction (or 0 degree), and 1 when reaching 90 degrees. A null value does not deviate the curve at all.
Shading normal, typically defined by bump or normal mapping. Defaults to the smooth surface normal if not set.
Shading normal, typically defined by bump or normal mapping. Defaults to the smooth surface normal if not set.
Indicates how pronounced the tail effect should be, ranging linearly from none at all, to full tail roughness.
Defines how rough the tail effect should appear, ranging from no roughness change at all, to a roughness of 1 (or to 0 with a negative value).
Defines the amount of anisotropy, changing the co-tangent axis roughness  from the original value toward 1 (or toward 0 with a negative anisotropy value).
Overrides the surface tangent as the anisotropy direction.
Rotates the anisotropy direction (possibly overriden by the previous attribute) around the normal, from 0 to 360 degrees.
When enabled, the IOR and refracted rays from layers above will be ignored, and the exterior IOR will be set manually.
Defines what the IOR of the exterior medium is (can be either the outside medium, eg. air or water, or in case of a layered material, the top layer medium, like plexiglass or varnish).
Switches the edge color parameterization. Belcour is an improved parameterization that provides a more linear response. Gulbrandsen is the common edge tint parameterization.

Indicates how much energy should be added to the lobe, to compensate for the loss inherent to micro-facet models, ranging from no compensation at all, to the expected energy from multiple scattering between the micro-facets. This prevents overly dark results when roughness is high.
When enabled, shadowing from bumped normals is considered. This helps to soften harsh shadow terminators.
Defines by how much the roughness can be increased based on local surface curvature. This can help prevent fireflies.
Defines by how much the roughness can be increased based on motion blur. This can help prevent fireflies.
Defines the name that can be used in LPE AOVs for this lobe.
Defines the name that can be used by the matte system, to output the weight of this lobe in the final material as an AOV.
